description: Just spent a weekend in the bay and while in s.f chinatown I happened to walk into this place with only browsing in mind. However, once inside it's impossible to resist the free tastings that ultimately lead to endless questions which Herman, by the way, answered  with such knowledge. A little over an hour later I walked away with a green detox, some pu erh and chysanthemum! This is a must visit anytime you're in  S.F. Needless to say, I will be back. Thanks!
author: Ryan V.

description: Had one of the most educational, entertaining tea tastings of my entire life. Mark and Uncle G. are INCREDIBLY knowledgable, and they extol the virtues of each very unique tea. Bought a delicious iron goddess monkey pick tea and a neat tea making mug!
author: Matthew G.

description:
The tea bar is a must!  It's a lot of fun to sample many different type of tea and the "bartenders" are super friendly, funny, as well as knowledgable.  (And yes, they are really good at marketing too, and got me to spend money :P )

Lots of tea choices, lots of selection, etc, would love to take my grandma here when she is visiting, maybe she can tell me if they are for realz and legit  :D  So far, I'm really enjoying my purchase!
author: Jessica L.

description: I loved this place, great atmosphere and service. She also gave me a really good deal and a free flowering tea =] They are well educated on their stuff.
author: Emily E.

description: AWESOME!!!  Even if you aren't a tea lover you will be when you leave here.  A trip to china town would not be complete without a 1/2 hour tea tasting experinece like no other.  BTW - it's FREE1  Yes, they sit you down and start pouring samples until you find what you like. Go when it's slow and get an amazing education on tea too.  See you there the next time i'm in SF or Seattle.
author: Mark C.

description: The crazy staff made it fun and enjoyable for a tea tasting. Would have stayed longer but had to catch my flight back home. Uncle Gee is halarious....Had a great time thanks!!!!!
author: Jerry S.

description: If you have some time for a cup of tea, check out uncle Gee and his family. Very knowledgable and hospitable. Lots of fun.
author: Nan B.

description:
We stopped by here on our visit through Chinatown.  I thought it would be neat to check out the various teas offered in an SF tea shop to see if there were any unique teas not available here in DC.  To our surprise the tea shop offered a free tea tasting of some of the teas for sale in the shop.  

Our tea expert gave us a mini lecture on the different types of tea and the medical and health benefits of drinking tea.  It was very informative and kinda neat to hear someone so knowledgeable about tea.
author: Jaemie D.

description: Friendly,  laid back,  and clean place to taste and learn about tea.  Come with an open mind.  Ask questions.    I learned quite a bit. I ended up sitting and chatting with Kenny and customers for almost 4 hours today.  They won't try to sell you anything you don't want and will discourage you from buying things you really don't need.   And yes,  they speak English very well!
author: Henry L.

description:
The tea itself it just okay, pretty authentic chinese tea.

Now, on the other hand, this is an awesome place to come for tea tasting in china town! They give you free fortune cookies and all kinds of different teas

Not gonna lie, I hated most of them (haha) but the guys working there kept telling me "tea is not for taste, it's for health".

There are like 3 or 4 of these vital leaf places in china town, if you want free tea all day, just hit all the spots!
author: Katlin L.

description:
"When you leave, you are a part of my family." - Uncle Gee

Read about it here: http://goo.gl/mPz0m

Experience it right here.

Invited to join the crowded tea bar as I walked in. Ultimately didn't buy anything yet had better customer service than most restaurants.

Over the next twenty minutes learned about staying healthy, washing toxins out and proper technique for brewing tea. 

Lessons were complemented with smooth Angel Green Tea, flavorful Lychee Tea and a few others. Wanted to take some home but don't have a loose leaf tea set.

Buying one will be a reason to return. Would love to see this family again.
author: Jason B.

description: One of our favorite places to visit when in SF. Free tea tasting and hilarious tea-tender. We always leave with a couple bags of tea and a new tea gadget.
author: Christine M.

description: This was the best "accidental find" of my entire vacation. Royal did our tea tasting and helped us pick out which teas we wanted to purchase. It was incredibly clear that he knew what he was talking about and loved his job. I'm a huge tea lover and really enjoyed what an educational experience going in there was. The tea was moderately priced, and we were all given generous samples to take home with us. I will be ordering tea from there as soon as I run out of what I purchased.  Very welcoming, and not pushy in the least to buy. I was able to get some Ginseng tea for 1/2 the price I had seen before. FANTASTIC experience.
author: Laura G.

description:
My lion dance group performed here and I'm also a regular popping in and out almost every week. I enjoy a all out of their interesting teas such as Lychee Blck (good for digestion), Angel Green (good for antioxidant and people worried about their figure), Blue Tea (good for people with anxiety) and High Mtn Tea. Uncle Gee is like my dad every time I go in along with cousin John, Jin and Ming. This place can be expensive depending on the type of tea you buy. But, since there's some free tasting and good humored people here, I like to come here before going to work. 

Ginseng Iron Goddess tea, definitely a must try and Blue people tea for those of you who need a chaser after some major drinking. hehehe Lovely place to bring your friends if you got some out of towners and its in Chinatown! Think CHEAP!!! ^.^
author: Jason C. J.

description: Awesome. Very informative and helpful. We stumbled upon this place and we were not disappointed. Free tea samples and education. We purchased Jasmine Pearl and Iron Goddess King. We tried 4 different teas before we made our decision. We were the last customers and the lady cut us a deal without us asking. We learned so much about tea. We will come back next time we visit. Highly recommend.
author: Casey T.

description: Their customer service sucks. I gave it a try today with my party of 3. The woman behind the counter was completely uninterested of our presence. We came with intentions of trying their tea and purchasing my favorite kind- Siberian rose tea. We stood at the door unattended for a good minute before we decided to take our seats next to another party. She quickly poured us a sample of Jasmine tea and tended to the older crowd next to us. She catered to them and had her back to us, making it hard to get her attention to try another sample. The crowd next to us were kind and chatted a bit with us before purchasing tea and leaving. Once they left the woman just stood back and avoided our glances! Obviously we didn't look like the "buying crowd" to her because we're young. I really wanted to get the Siberian rose tea, but will not support a company with such horrible customer service. We stood up, said thank you, and left. Of course she heard that and said thank you while quickly cleaning up our cups! If you are the young crowd and want to be ignored, please go to vital tea leaf. SMH
author: Ally S.

description:
This place is great.  Come here to learn about authentic Chinese tea and how to properly brew it.  Tasting is free, and you are welcome to stay for as long as you like, and you are not obliged to buy anything.  Each time I come, I stay at least an hour!

If you're new to tea, come with an open mind.  The Chinese staff are very direct--they will tell you what is quality and what is not, with little sugar-coating.  That's part of the fun; they're so discerning and passionate about their tea brewing, and they want to make sure their customers leave with a new understanding of tea.   Even if they poke some fun at your favorite sweet tea (I live in Texas, sometimes I enjoy a good sweet tea), they really are kind people trying to give you a new experience.  

If you're serious about tea (and a fan of light schadenfreude), enjoy the knowledgeable staff interrogate clueless tourists about how they drink their 5-minute brewed lipton, with quips like, "You put milk or sugar in, you're fired!"  

If you get to meet Uncle G, it's your lucky day.  He's a riot.  He travels to China each year to buy the best tea and bring it back to his stores.

Prices may appear steep (with some White teas at $180 per pound), but you can easily ask for $20 worth of tea, for example.  Since tea is so light, $20 worth of tea can actually last a few months!  Don't be scared by the weight price--buying in bulk is actually cheaper, and loose-leaf will always give you the best quality.
author: Ann K.

description:
It's been nearly 4 years since I first visited Vital Tea Leaf - since then, I've been back literally over 50 times! This is a "tea bar", which means you can sample any of the hundreds of kinds of tea they have for free. If you like it, feel free to buy some, but there is no pressure. I'd never heard of a place like this, but the concept is spectacular.

The variety of tea they have is staggering & any health issues you have, they can recommend a tea for that. :) The hosts treat everyone like family, cracking jokes & poking fun, so don't take ANY of that as an insult. When you visit, give yourself AT LEAST an hour to sit down & enjoy the presentation. If you're a fan of light, smooth-flavored tea, try Jasmine & Siberian Rose - my 2 personal favorites. I can't recommend this place enough - it is a hoot to visit, a diamond in the rough that is Chinatown, and every time I come back to visit San Francisco, this is the first place I go.
author: Victoria K.

description: Just came into Vital Leaf Tea again to get my fix.  Great teas, and outstanding service.  Mark helped me.  Super knowledgeable, super cool.   They actually want you to stay, relax and enjoy.  He didnt push me to buy more than I wanted. As s salesperson, i appreciate that.   Wouldn't go anywhere else!
author: Mark D.

description: Walked into the shop and Uncle Gee told us to sit down at the bar! Great experience with great choice of teas. Uncle Gee knows his stuff and he enjoys it! I bought the Angel Green Tea and Rose Tea, which are delicious. Since it was my birthday, Uncle Gee also gave me some flower tea as a present. Super nice and you can tell that he doesn't only care about money, but his customers as well.
author: Dragana O.

description: I have been drinking tea since I was 10 years old. I have to say the tea quality is okay. The service is good. It is definitely a fun place for tea tasting if you have friends from out of the town, but it is not the place where I would buy loose leaf from.
author: Yve H.

description:
This was the coolest thing we did our entire weekend in San Francisco!  I had never done a tea tasting before and so many of the teas were so good and the person doing the tasting was very entertaining and extremely knowledgable.  I ended up buying some tea, but its a free tasting, no strings attached.

Make sure you check it out!
author: Jacques S.

description: Vital Tea Leaf is a nice place to go. I like the variety of tea that they carry in the store. They are good for real tea drinkers who know their teas, as well as tea drinkers who see it as an beverage. 2oz=$15 (that's the least amount they would sell to me). The man I asked a few questions to came off a bit rude and was more interested to get back to whatever he was doing before I came in. The young lady was a lot more helpful and informative.
author: Kayla K.

description:
AMAZING!!!! This place is the to go place if you are a tea head like Brittney and I. We just came back, and seriously we are amazed. The owner, Kenny, is very kind, helpful and just great (he's the chinese version of Steven Seagal, I think they're twins!). 

Kenny gave us a good 45 minutes lesson about teas, we sampled a lot of them and purchased a couple different ones. Their Oolongs are great, but the Lychee is very good dessert choice as well.

Prices vary based on the rarity of the teas, you go from 30$ a lb. to 4000$ a lb., the selection is superb.
author: Giorgio B.

description: I walked in here randomly while I was showing some friends around chinatown. The employees were welcoming and offered us some free tastins. We sat and tried about 5 different teas which were brewed in front of us; he even gave us little explanations of the teas as he poured them which was nice. They were all unique and tasty, but a little pricey for my tea price range. Worth checking out if you are in the area!
author: Vinitha R.

description:
What a treat! 

My BMs and I were strolling around Chinatown during my Bachelorette Party weekend in San Fran when we stumbled across this GEM! 

Ming showed us an incredible time. He was not only hilarious but taught us so much about the different kinds of teas. Half-way through the tasting out came his 81 year old father who was an absolute hoot. Not only did he offer me some marital advise but it was awesome to see father and son interact. 

I think our day would not have been the same without this experience at Vital Tea. THANKS!!
author: Femia M.

description:
Touristy spot but its won me over even as a local. Must have visited here half a dozen times. I love bringing friends from out of town and introducing them to our Vital Tea expert Herman while sipping some tea. 

They are extremely knowledgeable about tea and its benefits. They even have creatively engineered tea brewers. They are not about a hard sale, they let their knowledge, tea quality, and service do the selling.
author: Nelson C.

description:
Okay so I'm from new York and I love tea and I am not easily swayed but  .I wish we had a place like this back home no pressure ,very knowledgable staff ,friendly in your living room feel. 
Herman was great what ever I wanted to try was no problem and  then he showed me his picks great place.
I brought some great tea at good prices met some good people and all in all had a great time.
I will be asking them to ship to me which they tell me is no problem if your in SF stop in  I know when I come back I will be stopping here again.
To top it all off their pick for Chinese food was fantastic as well
author: LOUIS K.

description: I came here for the first time with my friend (a veteran customer here) yesterday. Best part of my week! This place was amazing. I'm a new "tea-goer" and had lost of questions. I was a bit nervous as I've never been had a "tea tasting session" and didn't want to insult anyone with my lack of etiquette however it was not an issue at all! "Uncle" (the owner) was not there however his son (whom I now refer to as "Cousin") was phenomenal. He was helpful as well as entertaining. He spent an hour explaining things to me and pouring me shot after shot of different teas. I left with two types as well as accessories and instructions on what to do. He explained things to me in a child-like-manner (as I told him would be the most helpful way to me) and I left happy as a clam! The other guy working there was also awesome and friendly. Customers that happened to be there when I was also left happy. I love this place!
author: Justine J.

description: We had a great experience at VTL. It is both an educational and entertaining experience well worth a visit for locals and travelers alike.
author: Chris P.

description: Great place to buy delicious tea, and to sit and sample some new ones.
author: Jacqueline W.

description:
Free tea tastings? YES PLEASE!

The lady here let us try as many teas as we wanted. We ended up walking out with 1/4 pound of the lychee green tea, which was a huge bag for just $15 bucks!

I don't drink black tea, but they had some awesome tasting black and white teas too!
author: Amuse B.

description:
I was in SF on vacation last week and one of the places I wanted to go - was Chinatown.  I'm not into all the little trinkets and tourist glam - but I am big into tea...

I visited this place three seperate times during my vacation, once to grab some tea, once to grab a tea set, and then again to grab a tea table to complete the whole ideology...

The customer service is awesome, the music they play is awesome, their selection of teas and accessories is kick ass - it's just an awesome place all around so you should check it out...

DO IT!!
DO IT NOW!!!

...and don't forget to stop by Pernicious Attire to check out all our wicked awesome clothing!!

YEAH!!!
author: Silvansaria X.

description:
On a rainy day my mom and I stopped at Vital tea leaf to see if they had strawberry green tea. I had never been there before and I soon realized that I had stumbled on a gem. 

The young man behind the counter asked us if we wanted to try any tea and we gladly took a seat. From there we must have tried at least 10 different teas while learning about each of them. I left Vital Tea Leaf with lychee black tea and a new favorite spot in Chinatown. I highly suggest taking the time to visit this tea shop and try some of their amazing teas especially blue people.
author: rebecca p.

description: Great selection of teas and awesome service.  A must-visit!
author: Virginia C.

description: Epic spot in Chinatown, got to try some interesting teas with the Uncle. My favorite was the angel tea ( 3 - 4 day ) and the puer tea that was aged in the orange peel. I only wanted a small amount ( $5 worth) so they gave it to me on the house and refused my money. I'm trying to figure out the chinese name for the angel tea, so if anyone knows, let me know. I'd return anytime to try the tea and enjoy the humor.
author: Brian J.

description:
This is a great thing to do in China Town, but if you dont like death threats than this place prolly isnt for you. We were wandering around and came across a place promising free tea tasting. When we got inside, the old, Chinese host ( Uncle Gee) shouted " IF YOU DONT LIKE MY TEA, I WILL BEAT YOU TO DEATH. SIT DOWN." We sat. 
The place itself is pretty cute, with gold canisters of every kind of tea lining the walls. You sit at a long table, and everyone gets an adorable tea cup. Before the tea tasting began, Uncle Gee asked my boyfriend if I was his girl and then leaned down, grabbed me by the chin and said " You wanna go out?" These are only a few of the things you may experience at Vital Tea Leaf. 
The tea tasting itself is pretty awesome. Uncle Gee lectures about the proper way to prepare tea, and then gives you cup after cup, all completely free. We were there about a half hour before we decided to take off, and they gave me a free blossom tea thingy too! I highly recommend this place to anyone not afraid of being yelled at
author: Kim R.

description:
This was the real high point of our visit to Chinatown.  

As we looked over the teas on the south wall around 3 pm, "I'm not Chinese" John urged us to have a seat and enjoy a FREE tea tasting.  Well, how do you turn down "free?"  We sat.  

John used a constant patter of jokes and anecdotes to pass the time while he and another clerk steeped a round of teas, about one every 3 minutes, for a half hour.  Going from light to dark, he explained the origins and qualities of each tea, to what rapidly became a full bar of twenty-somethings getting their Far East culture on.  

The ones I noted were:  

     Jasmine pearl white - the sweetest jasmine I have tasted in 30 years 

     Siberian rose 

     Milk oolong - buttery flavor - $120-160/lb. 

     Puehr - smoky, like the peat in scotch - $70/lb. 

     Angel - bitter, yet the best medicinal - $160/lb.  

     Lychee black - real lychee flavor 

     Guan Yin - $800/lb.  

The teas are most commonly sold in 4 oz. canisters, and all the teas are loose leaf.  

While some of the flatter jokes left us feeling told, overall we found we had been entertained and educated.  Don't quit your day job, John.  Oh, wait ... 

Bottom line:  Our guest bought 3 canisters of tea.
author: David D.

description:
I was randomly wandering through Chinatown with my dear friend and her kids when we came upon this place.  Actually, her daughter was looking for an entirely different tea place, but as it was getting late and she wasn't quite sure where it was, we passed by and decided to try this place instead.

Upon entering, we were immediately invited to sit at the counter and sample several of their teas.  We were first served a white jasmine (per my friend's request), in a clear glass pitcher.  Watching the little tealeaf balls unfold was almost as good an experience as the tea itself, which was quite tasty.

The guy was friendly and knowledgeable, explaining the supposed benefits of each tea.  I take these benefit explanations with a grain of salt, having worked in pharmaceutical companies for years and knowing there is no real physical evidence that any of these teas actually do what the salesperson might say.  Next time I will ask exactly how much I need to drink and how often to actually feel any benefits.

Still, the entertainment value of the server, his salespitch, and the taste of the tea itself was well worth the experience.  Especially good was the "milk oolong" tea, which is irrigated with milk before being harvested and picks up the aroma, and once brewed, does indeed taste like milk is already added.

It's obvious that the servers are well-trained by good businessmen, because many of these teas are quite expensive sold by the pound (one canister of some type of "goddess" tea was listed at 800 dollars per pound!).  But he immediately started making a comparison to buying a cup of Starbucks every day, saying that you would ultimately spend more, because a pound of tea lasts longer.  He might be correct on this, but to me it was just another part of the salespitch.

Nevertheless, the product sold itself, and I was happy to purchase the milk oolong purely for the taste.  Also recommended is the "blue people" tea, and the ginseng varieites, which are a bit less expensive.
author: Paul W.

description:
Loved the free tea tasting! 

Karina (?) was very knowledgeable about the different types of tea and recommended some great ones to try. Very unique flavors! We ended up getting the lychee green tea, rose, and milk oolong. 

The only thing that could be improved is more background on the different types of tea. I heard from a friend I went with that other people here explain more about the origins of the tea, roasting process, etc.
author: Diane C.

description:
My first time tea tasting, it was fun! Why can't all first times be this enjoyable.

Let me just say this: it is not a place for poor/broke college students lol. The teas here are kaching! kaching!

The tea-tenders were lovely, they really know their teas! I love the way they make the tea, pour the tea, explain the benefits of the tea! My favorite that I tasted was "blue people" tea, it had a sweet after-taste that really lingers in your mouth! At $120/lb though, I couldn't afford it. It's just "not my cup of tea"....

.....yeah, that was my joke of the day.....
author: Emmie N.

description:
Leaving this review just because I am such a fan.

Look, if you want cheap, poor quality tea, go buy it at Safeway.  If you want real tea, tea leaves, and the best way to drink it, come here.  You get what you pay for.  Pay for scraps that fall on the floor, go to Safeway.  Pay for good stuff that allows you to watch the leaves bloom and release, and use over and over again, come here.  

Come here.  Drink tea.  Buy tea.  Your life will be better for it.
author: HQ G.

description: Walking through China town and peeked into this place and had to go in.  Very nice people working there immediately offered me samples of tea.  I tried a bunch of varieties I had never had before.  All perfectly preppared.  Needless to say I bought some.  Some varieties are very pricey but very good quality.
author: Robert P.

description:
By all means, buy the tea, but honestly, there are many other places that sale the same tea for a tenth of the price or less.  DO come here for the experience of being served by your new Chinese uncle, Uncle Gee.  If you are a woman, prepare to be flattered (in a way that a respectable uncle would never try to flatter his nieces).

I'm wary to walk through the door of any of the tourist-infested restaurants and kitsch bazaars in Chinatown, but Uncle Gee makes this place a real gem.  If you want to drink free tea at a tea bar ("not a d*mn tea room" as Uncle Gee says) and be thoroughly entertained for a good hour or so, take a short walk over from Market Street and be seated at Vital Tea Leaf.
author: Jesse M.

description: We stumbled upon Vital when walking through China Town on vacation from Iowa. How lucky! Uncle Gee was a joy and so informative. We were given countless samples and stories and life lessons to match each cup. It was one of the highlights of our trip.
author: Kristin S.

description:
This place is great. I only visited the tea tasting room, not the four story tea house where you can buy $1500/pound teas by the KILO. While most of the finer teas were out of my personal price range, this place has a selection for all tea lovers with wallets of any size.

The greatest part of the tea tasting room is how they explain the medical benefits of all the types of tea. As explained to me by our tea-tender, in Asia tea is used for its medicinal purposes first. Are you sick? Tired? Constipated? Horny? Lonely? Need to cut the grease out of your diet? I was left with the impression that there was a tea for just about anything.

They also show you how to brew their tea properly (hot but not boiling water, usually no longer than 30 seconds, pour hot water over the leafs first to "activate" all the good stuff). After 10 rounds of samples I am converted. I am going to be drinking a lot of tea now, and I am definitely going back here and taking all my friends!
author: Evan K.

description: The family that runs this place are about as cool/goofy as it gets. Came in with a cold, left we some tea to help calm the sinuses and a recommendation on some stuff, (white flower) that has really helped, sold by the shop next door.
author: Colin G.

description:
LOSE YOURSELF IN TEA WORLD!

Me and a friend stopped in, thinking we could get a cup of tea and leave, but instead our hostess, showed us about 5 different samples, from green to blue to black to herbal tea and a puerh tea, telling us the history and notes behing each sip, didn't feel pressured to buy anything, but my friend left with a box of his favorite Jasmine (i think) and a box of blooming tea. 

so many options, and if you have the time, i am sure you can try them all.
author: Alisson X.

description:
While the critique is fair on the pricing, there are some places you go knowing you go for the spectacle, the service, or the "it" that some places have.  Vital Tea is one such place.  They staff was a ton of fun on a late Saturday night, and the knowledge of tea was amazing.  We bought a few of their more humble teas just to try Chinese style tea.  

It is not everyone's cup of tea (ha!  what a pun!) but still an enjoyable experience for all, regardless of what you think of their prices.  If you want to bargain shop, stay home and surf CL.  

The aroma of this place is worth a visit, and try the blue jasmine tea.  It will not disappoint.
author: Zakk D.

description: I'm pretty sure Mark has his PhD in tea. I've never known someone how knows so many intricate details about tea- history, processing, taste, how it affects your body, etc. I was super impressed and will definitely head back for another session b/c there are SO many teas to try. I ended up buying the "blue people" oolong; which I highly recommend. Another thing - there was no pushy sales tactic here. They are really just trying to educate you on teas and let you taste many varieties.
author: Laura W.

description:
Thinking of going on one of those fabulous time-share paid vacations, test how resistant your signing fingers are at this place first.  These guys would try to sell shoes to a shoe salesman.  

I am familiar with the tea basics, but I have no real depth of knowledge of teas.  But what I do have is a nose for b.s.  These guys did feed me some lines of it.  But this close to the holidays, and all the traveling that I am doing, I really didn't care as I had no time to look around for a good tea shop.  These guys offered me free samples, so I could taste what I was purchasing for someone, because I know generally what type of taste she has.  

So Vital Tea afforded me the opportunity to taste each one, and that was what it came down to.  All in all, I know it was somewhat a ripoff, but shopping is almost done, and I can focus on other more pressing matters.  

If you have time, look around, I am quite sure you can find cheaper and same if not better quality elsewhere.  If time is short, then like me, do what you have to do.

I am giving them a 3.5.  It is what it is here.
author: Soh Jai R.

description:
Any place with a lime green balustrade, turquoise ceiling, and yellow lanterns gets Certified Jennie Approval.  The fact that Vital Tea Leaf sells and lets you sample some excellent and unusual tea - well, that's just the tasty icing on the rainbow-colored cake.

I first wandered here in 2007, while showing off Chinatown to my best friend.  We ended up splitting a quarter pound of tea between the two of us, unable to resist the hot deliciousness.

Make sure you sit down and actually sample the tea.  Sometimes you can try 5-6, sometimes upwards of 15, depending on how busy it is.   James, the gentleman who has been working Saturday afternoons the last two times I've been there, is nice to everyone I bring in there, including angsty teenagers.  He's funny, explains the benefits/tasting notes of each tea, and never makes anyone feel like they've just asked a dumb question.  

Teas range from $13-$150 per quarter pound, but they will be quick to tell you that you can brew several cups of tea from one tablespoon of tea leaves.  I can attest that this is the truth!

My personal favorite is Blue People, but I noticed they have lemongrass tea...so I may be back a bit earlier than I had planned.  For the tea...and to bask in the righteous color palette.
author: Jennie K.

description:
I had no idea there could be so many different kinds of tea.  One wall of this place (which is long and skinny, like many store fronts in Chinatown) is completely covered with tins of different types of tea, maybe 100 in my estimation.

You sit down at the bar where a friendly tea pourer/educator asks you what you like and pours some different kinds for you to try.  I don't remember the name of the guy who we had, but he was your typical fobby Chinese guy.  He was very friendly and made a couple of jokes that most of the tourists laughed at.  Innocent enough.

We tried maybe a dozen types of tea in the 30 minutes we were there and then bought a cute tea cup set and some small tea tins to give as gifts.  I always feel guilty at places like this if I don't buy something since they are so nice and we did sample so many types of tea.  

All in all, a cute little place to bring people if they are visiting from out of town, or if you desire some rare kind of Chinese tea.
author: Maxine S.

description:
After spending the day playing tourist in SF, my friend mentioned he wanted to do a tea tasting.  We then casually walked into Vital Tea Leaf and my expectations were blown out of the water.  We were greeted by John John Allegre, who then proceeded to give us not only an education on tea but a 90 minute comedy show. 

Aside from learning that the Celestial Seasonings tea is the stuff picked up off the floor of a factory, John John showed us the VAST differences in teas from China.  He described the teas like it was wine.  Being in the wine industry, it was so easy to understand the flavor, color and style differences.  He described as a preventative medicine, something to be drunk every day but pairing the particular tea with the current symptoms one would have.  A tea for cleansing the liver, a tea to aid in circulation, and so on.  

John John doesn't make you buy anything but his sales pitch is one of the best I have ever seen.  I ended up spending a lot but the amount of tea I brought back goes a long way.  Do something different and get an education and walk in.
author: Arik C.

description: Walked into this place by accident and received a fantastic education as well as a plethora of tea flavors. For someone who has always wanted to be a wine snob and failed miserably, I was able to find my stride in learning to be a complete tea snob, luxuriating in the fine notes of ginseng and jasmine.
author: Hang B.

description: Stumbled in to browse, but uncle made me sit and try the most interesting teas I've ever had. What a great experience.
author: Carlos P.

description:
An awesome place to stop by after a great meal from one of the nearby restaurants.

Was just walkin' by, and with the weather gettin' a little nippy, couldn't help but teeter into this lovely tea shop.

Laid out in a bar like area, with huge jars of various teas left and right.

The service is superb, given the awesome personality of our host. Didn't catch his name, but he definitely knew his shit when it came to teas. Very friendly and personable to say the least.

I'm no aficionado when it comes to tea, as I stick with your main standby's of oolong, jasmine, and some barley wheat tea. But the folks here will blow your mind with the wide array of teas available for tasting and eventual purchase.

Prices range from $12/quarter lbs. to $20+. They advertise that it would last you three weeks, based on a "big pinch" of tea that lasts five servings.... I won't lie. You're paying a premium here, and for all I know - it might be too much. But taking into account the service and knowledge base provided to you, it's not something I can really complain about.

I picked up two quarters, one being a Blue Tea, and the other a Lychee variant. Great stuff.

I plan on coming back here next time, to expand my horizons in the tea world. And quite possibly purchase a pound or two for my ol' ma.
author: Isaac H.

description: My friend and I decided this place is going to be our annual meetup place. Every time we have gone or the past 2 time we have gone, we had a blast with Kenny. He is very knowledgeable and hilarious. The teas may seem expensive, you get your moneys worth because you can use the leaves over and over again. This place has a free tea tasting, but you leave feeling smarter because of all the stuff you have learned. If I could give them more stars, I would.
author: Jenny T.

description: Got seriously drunk off of the non-stop tea they serve you. Then ended up purchasing tea out of guilt. The tea was definitely overpriced as my parents can get them for so much cheaper in Taiwan. Also, I went downstairs to their bathroom where they have kegloads of tea. I remember our server, Ling, who was pretty cool.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
after a day spent walking around fisherman's warf, north beach and chinatown, the out-of-towners i was guiding wanted to buy some tea as a gift for someone.

we stumbled upon vital tea leaf and a big sign that said "free tea tasting". the man behind the counter saw our hesitation and called (almost forced) us in, sat us down, and served us almost half a dozen different kinds of teas. he also gave us as many spicy rice crackers and fortune cookies as we could eat. the whole process took a little over 30 minutes.

as we sat, i realized how lucky we were to have gotten our seats, as a line began to form outside.

all in all this shop came at a perfect location and served the perfect beverage for a nice little break from our walk. i will be back.
author: Tyler b.

description: I was looking forward to a fun and educational experience.  Instead I felt pushed through a tasting session.  I was utterly ignored by the young man leading the group--he was too busy setting up a date with the woman sitting next to me.
author: P. D.

description:
The gang had gone to SF for a weekend of debauchery and by Saturday morning, it had caught up to me.  As we were meandering around Chinatown, we happened upon this tea bar - something I never imagined existed.  

As we entered we were cheerfully greeted and asked to take a seat at the bar.  I'm not used to bars that are so well lit or where alcohol is absent, but I stayed nonetheless.  The proprietor asked me what aliled me and I said I was hungover.  While everyone else in the place laughed, he began grabbing tiny handfuls of tea and within a minute I had a small cup of tea in front of me. 

For the next hour and a half my friends and I sampled teas and learned a great deal from the wise man behind the counter.  We each purchased about fifty dollars worth of tea and tea related products, such as the awesome brewing cup which runs $20.  (It is also available on their website.  I know this because one of our cool cups did not survive the trek home!).

By the time I left, the hangover had settled to a dull roar and I have been drinking tea every day since.  In fact, I have completely given up coffee in favor of tea, not by design, but by desire.  I simply feel better and my energy is more consistent with tea as opposed to coffee.

By the way, there is absolutely NO pressure to buy anything here.  MANY people came, drank, and left without paying a dime.  The proprietors are equally friendly to all.  This is a must do if you're in the area.
author: Ted G.

description:
Now I adore tea. I love it and drink it everyday. I love trying different flavors, blends, and brands. 

Vital Tea Leaf was near where I was having dim sum and it looked interesting. Sitting down at the bar, I was highly entertained by John, who has a bawdy sense of humor and a very serious love for tea.  I do like the different teas we sampled, my favorite being the Angel Green Tea. 

It has a very local flavor despite getting a lot of traffic from tourists. Be aware that the tea they charged IS expensive but of good quality. I'm not sure how often I'll be in Chinatown but I would definitely stop by when I am.
author: Julia W.

description: I loved my experience here. I came in to get a packet of supreme jasmine, and the tea was phenomenal! I was allowed to sample the tea along with several other teas, and all were pretty great. The lady who worked there was very knowledgeable in her craft, and was very helpful in answering all of your questions about tea and its preparation. I will definitely stop by again when I'm in town, and plan on ordering all of my teas from their online store. The website is vitaltealeaf.net for anyone who would like to know.
author: Minji Y.

description:
I walked into this tea shop looking for a Xmas gift. As I walked in, there was an active tea tasting going on. It was being conducted by an older chinese fellow who was a riot. The man has the gift of creating comedy. He was yelling at people as they passed by the outside of his shop. "What you don't want to learn about tea?" I can't do a good job but this guy was great.

I plan on going back with a few other adults next time I'm in SF. I didn't get an opportunity to really stay and learn because I had 7 kids and a wife in tow.

I did buy a tea and can't wait to give it as a gift!
author: D C.

description:
As we wandered through Chinatown, dad who is a great tea drinker, was intrigued to see customers in this tea bar. A few minutes watching the customers seated at the bar showed us that they were being given samples of the many teas available in the shop to try.

So dad and I gave it a bash. An amazing experience. The range of teas is endless and they'll patiently make and pour you different types to try. Complimentary fortune cookies available but the teas are the star.

They will sell you any amount/cost of tea that you request.

A free version of Yumchaa that I recently came across in the UK. Hmm, another business opportunity perhaps?
author: Yee Gan O.

description: Do yourself a favor. Stop into this shop and sit with Uncle Gee for about an hour and a half and thoroughly enjoy yourself. I've been to San Fran about 5 times and this was one of the most interesting and fun experiences I've had. Learned a lot about the teas and Uncle Gee kept us laughing the whole time. Tastings are free and no pressure to buy. If you do choose to buy some tea like we did, the quality is great and the prices are very reasonable considering the high quality. I'll definitely be back.
author: Brian S.

description: My mom and I have been to this tea store four times.  Sometimes we go to Chinatown just to go here.  We love trying all the tea and the friendly atmosphere.  There is not much pressure to buy and they will sometimes give you deals.  Its a tad pricey but they sell the best tea we have ever had.  And its fresh too.
author: Michelle C.

description: I only wish I could give this place zero stars.  I took my two teenagers to this place to sample teas and buy some.  We sat down at the bar and waited.  And waited.  The people elbow to elbow on our left and right were being served, the jerk pouring was babbling on and on to the customers to our right, foul language included, but never served us anything.  A nicer guy came along and put cups in front of us and told the old guy to serve us some tea, but he didn't.  Just kept talking on and on and never looked our way once.  We finally just got up and left.  Unbelievable.
author: Rose H.

description:
As we Yelped our way through San Francisco we saw the sign "FREE Tea Tasting". Ha, "free" anything will catch my eye. FYI, I don't even like tea but I like "free"! So, my sisters and I wander in and sit down at the counter with a handful of other out-of-towners.

One hour later, I'm educated on the benefits of tea, I've spent close to $100 on tea and I am now drinking tea everyday! They seriously converted this coffee drinker into a tea drinker. First thing I learned, you don't drink Chinese tea for the taste (duh, doesn't taste that great). I was told you drink it for a purpose. Can't remember the guy's name but when we sat down, he asked if we had any ailments. Well, my son (15) has always had a tough time sleeping through the night. So I asked him what would help. He recommended the Jasmine Pearl. I made my son a cup the night I returned from SF and he has slept through the night since. I bought 2 other teas and an Easy Push Button Strainer Glass Tea Mug (love it!). 

I will definitely go back next time I'm in SF! There is no hard sell, they were very informative and taught me how to make and drink tea. Great experience!
author: Grace B.

description:
This place is so fun! My boyfriend and I were visiting San Francisco for my birthday, and we were amused by the "Tea Free Tasting" sign (poor wording. LoL). You can try as many teas as you like. The tea master that served us was awesome. We got schooled on tea, and I think I've gotten my bf one step closer to giving up soda. You should definitely stop by here!

This is one of a bagillion reviews that I am posting from my San Francisco Birthday 2010 Trip. Check 'em out!
author: Kate C.

description: YAY free tea tasting.  Great customer service.  The guy was so helpful explaining about the types of teas and how it can help your health.  We had plans to do more sightseeing but I loved it there so we stayed there for a good bit trying teas.  There was so many varieties to try but my favorite was the ginseng iron maiden tea.  Kinda sad that I'm visiting the bay area but the best thing you can order on-line. :)
author: Nekiba M.

description: Fiancee and I spent a little while here just kicking it and drinking free tea. We made some friends too in this cozy little shop. I felt that the server (didn't catch a name here) was super chill and willing to let us try whatever we wanted. I've been dearly missing my hong cha and otherwise properly made tea since I lived in Taiwan.. this place offered us refreshment and respite. Walked out with some Oolong Milk Tea (very exotic) and something like gunpowder tea. Very cool indeed.
author: Crystal J.

description: I've been here twice (at two different locations) and enjoyed the tea education mixed with humor.  The staff are incredibly entertaining... that's part of the charm.  They will poke fun at how Americans drink tea, but do it in a ligth-hearted way, so don't take it too seriously or be offended.  One host said we drink "hot dog" tea -- those Lipton teabags are filled with a bunch of whoknowswhat.  Another hostess gave us a sample of the cleansing teas (a pungent smelling, very tannic liquid).  When someone asked for clarification on "cleansing", she broke it down:  It makes you "poo poo".  Haha!  I appreciate toilet humor, so I wasn't mortified that she was trying to educate me and my (first) date on what teas can help us with our "cleansing".  FREE hot tea tasting on a foggy San Francisco afternoon?  Can't beat it.
author: April G.

description:
Life is sometimes hard for a Chinese person. Our reckless driving habits, toddler death toys and enviable math supremacy certainly do not help. Luckily, for every Jackie Chan and apathetic waiter comes a respectable business like Vital Tea Leaf, offering a variety of delicious teas and wonderful service. The proprietor, an amicable Malaysian Chinese, creates a pleasurable and fun tasting experience as he regales us with stories of his travels mixed with a plethora of tea facts. A customer once asked to pay for tea training, he tells us, to which he replied, "I don't charge for knowledge. Knowledge is free."

And as all the happy white people hang on his every word, I find pride in my heritage. So proud, in fact, that I'm more than ready to triple park in the Richmond to go haggle for an orange.
author: Keane L.

description:
Oh Uncle Gee!

Two LA boys decided they wanted tea.  They walked in and ask for tea and jokingly asked for a side of vodka.  Uncle Gee pulls out gin.  This guy is a major hoot!  Not only did we sit for 30 min while he educated us on tea, he manage to advised us on our dating lives and gave all the guys Chinese viagra tea (its OX tea for all you guys..)  Tea is pricey - but Uncle Gee can sell.  You don't come in just for the complimentary tea...you also gain an Uncle.  Ask him about his life - he has lived an amazing one!  We def got more than we bargained for!
author: Julie H.

description: I wandered in based on a travel guide write up.  What a wonderful place.  Way fun, great staff and the tea was sublime.  I could not recommend it more highly.  I loved the Blue People green tea.  I came as a loose leaf black tea person, and left wanting to know more about green and all the fine vital teas.  I'm glad I took notes.
author: Jane C.

description:
So I like to consider myself a tea drinker. I have my bag teas for the mornings with agar and my loose leaf teas for the evenings. I am a fan of white teas and know what a good oolong should taste like.

I went into Vital Leaf today on my way to Yong Kee for bows during lunch. Just passing by the store, I had to go inside to look at their selection. The selection was vast and had an array of interesting combinations. I didn't intend to sit down for the touristy tea ceremony with flourish and showmanship, but I did sit down. I am very glad I did that too.

John served me an assortment of teas. The white rose, the lychee black, one of the expensive green teas behind the counter, etc. He was friendly and for my lunch hour, we discussed business and local politics combined with an assortment of dirty jokes. Surprisingly, a lot of our conversation was in french and I really did have a fun lunch hour with proper tea preparation, fortune cookies, some informative medical information and a fun story.

Yes, I know it's pricey (it's Chinatown and a very touristy spot, duh) but I feel the customer service more than makes up for everything the shop lacks (since most of Chinatown lacks customer service). I had a great time and spent $12 on a quarter pound of lychee black tea. Could I have purchased the same tea elsewhere for cheaper? Probably. Would I have had as much fun? Most certainly not.

I felt the lychee black here was better quality than Imperial Tea Court (which is cheaper) and was loads cheaper than Teance on 4th street in Berkeley (like $15 for 2oz of rose black tea at that shop). Less pretentious and not afraid to have fun with tea. I had a good time, you should too. Good for locals and tourists (as I saw many locals coming into the store to give John a hug and shoot the breeze, which I may also do from time to time).

-1 star because what the hell is blue tea? There's no such thing as blue tea. Even I know that.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I love this place. 
I love the tea but I love spending an afternoon chewing the fat with John more. 
He is full of knowledge and advice (and some great dirty jokes and remarks)
Try 'Golden Throat' and Johns special 'Passion' (only for his fav customers).
Healthy and fun!
author: Kitty S.

description: I'm always up for green tea in the mornings or early in the afternoon when I need to sit down and get some work done. I was walking in Chinatown trying to make some time until the restaurant I was interested in opened. I then remembered that I was short in supplies for green tea at home and probably I would get good tea around the area. I yelped tea shops and this place was the closer and best rated at hand. I entered the place and was surprised by the amount of teas they had. After wandering for a while, they asked me which one I wanted to try. I said no idea, I like green tea! (Sometimes having many options can be detrimental). They prepared two different teas for me, while doing that they explained the adequate preparation of green tea: no boiling water, first simmer needs to be thrown away and the subsequent simmers need to be of approx 30 sec (now I understand what went wrong on previous occasions). I like the green tea with ginseng and took a small recipient of it. A little expensive I might say but they swear it will last up to a year. Will keep you posted!
author: Sol A.

description:
Vital Tea Leaf is a nice place to go and get a few free cups of tea during a cold, rainy day in Chinatown.  The staff is friendly, but be aware that they *will* try to get you to buy tea.  Don't buy their tea - their prices are ridiculous.  Instead, consider them a place to sample tea, soak up some ambiance, and have friendly conversation.  Make note of the teas you like, and then find them on the Internet at much cheaper prices.  They are good salesmen; don't let them push you into buying and don't believe all the health claims they make.  

Just go there and sip tea.  :)
author: Asteridae A.

description: Best Tea Shop, period.  Ming and his staff are knowledgeable, friendly and welcoming.  Drank tea with them for 2-3 hours and ended up buying 5 different varieties of tea that i enjoy daily.
author: Kelly M.

description:
The people who work at Vital Tea Leaf are the most hilarious people ever.  I asked them about teas to help you sleep, and the guy behind the counter said with mock disgust, "You don't drink tea to sleep!  You want to sleep? Drink THIS!" and pulled a bottle of Tanqueray out from under the counter.

Delicious teas.  But EXPENSIVE, I'm warning you.  Nevertheless, they gave me a free tea flower to take home and show off to my roommates.
author: Caroline M.

description:
The pros: I think it's great that people are starting to enjoy tea and I think it's nice that a shop in Chinatown has piqued the interest of new and veteran tea fans.  I am new to tea as well, but it looks like the selection at Vital Tea is pretty decent and they seem pretty knowledgeable.  

The cons: Their "pushy-ness" and I was extremely put off when the staff bad-mouthed a few of the other tea shops on Grant Avenue.  I would agree that their people know their stuff, at least coming from a tea newbie's point-of-view, and talking about your products and service is fine...but when you boast that you're the only real tea shop and "everyone else sells fake tea" and say that it's not worth anybody's time to go to another shop...that's a real concern to me as it gives people the wrong impression about Chinatown and Chinatown retailers.  

I haven't had a chance to compare prices, but I would agree with most of the other reviews in that their prices are on the high side.  

Other notes: I was interested in the review posted by "teapot .." about "white dragonwell", and I will be the first to say that I am not an expert by any means, so forgive me if my research is inaccurate, but I found something out there that's called "Bai Longjing" which FWIW is described as "Not a true Longjing but looks like one and is commonly attributed, it is actually a Bai Pian. It comes from Anji in the Zhejiang Province. It was created in the early 80's and is a Green tea from a race of White tea trees and is hence very unusual, it is said to contain more amino acids than ordinary Green tea."  

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longjing

So maybe "white dragonwell" does exist?  But if what the young woman at Vital Tea brought out looked like Silver Needle, then that probably was Silver Needle since Silver Needle doesn't look at all like Bai Longjing according the pictures on TeaSpring.com.  

http://www.teaspring.com/Bai-Long-Jing.asp

http://www.teaspring.com/Bai-Hao-Yin-Zhen.asp

Anyway, just my two cents.
author: D C.

description:
I love Yelp, but hate all the pretentiousness. 

Stopped in to Vital Tea Leaf, had an AWESOME time joking around with the--yes, extremely charismatic--staff. Maybe I'm wrong, but I kinda like that?? Maybe I go into a tea place (*shocking!!!*) ......expecting to buy tea?? Expecting that someones going to try and sell me tea? 

I mean, especially with free tasting. And in Chinatown.

Yeah maybe I missed out on my tea snob degree. The one where you trade in your humility and social skills for a license to write wikipedia articles and website reviews across the blogosphere about how much you know about tea and have traveled to ancient and foreign lands proving just how much bigger your tea penis is than everyone else's tea penis. 

But maybe I just like people more than I like tea.

Maybe I like Uncle Gee and his witty banter and his *gasp again!* ACTUALLY HAVING FUN TALKING ABOUT TEA. 

Maybe I don't penny-pinch about everything thats just going to end up going down my throat because hey maybe sometimes I go to places for the experience. I mean, it's not like I go out to like Olive Garden or something complaining that the food was marked up 700%, because you know what? Sure Olive Garden isn't the most authentic Italian joint on the block--but no one f'n cares because they still love it.

No one feels like they're being "ripped off" when they're somewhere they enjoy themselves, and I guarantee--come in here expecting to laugh with the staff and have a good conversation, and you'll end up on the five star side of this Yelp divide. Sure, you'll buy some tea--but buy a couple like 2 ounce sample bags and you'll leave only 20 bucks lighter, and a lot more satisfied than if you had spent the time online listening to "experts" telling you about the "absolute best value in tea."
author: Kyle S.

description:
In contrary to some of the bad reviews on yelp, I didn't feel that the owner was pushy. He was quite patiently educating my friends and I about green, black, and white teas. I grew to appreciate tea so much more now. My friends and I had a blast doing tea tasting. And it's free!

The teas can be a bit expensive, but good teas are expensive. I'm sure you can find similar teas for really cheap else where. But great teas are expensive. 

I'd also recommend J-Tea a tea company based in Eugene, OR. The owner posts tons of educational videos on teas. That may help you understand why good teas can be expensive.
author: William L.

description: This is a must try in San Francisco.  In the heart of Chinatown, lies this gem.  They have a great selection of teas to offer, but the best part is you can sit down and try them all first before you buy.  If you do not know much about tea, you can come here and the knowledgeable staff will tell you everything you need to know.  They do tea tastings and tell you about the benefits of tea, quality, taste, etc.  They definitely know how to show you a GREAT time.  This place will not disappoint.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
Vital Tea Rocks! Uncle Gee and Ming are super friendly and super helpful. Not only did they give me great tea samples and totally make me feel like family, they ran all over Chinatown to help me get a 65# pig to roast just because I asked if they knew of a butcher nearby. Talk about good service!

The basics: Vital Tea Leaf is a tea shop on a busy street (full of tourists that don't likely know much about tea outside of Lipton) that gives free tea samples and makes non-tea drinkers and tea-drinkers alike feel comfortable exploring their tea-ness. The staff is entertaining and charismatic and it's fun to sample different teas.
author: Melissa R.

description:
The reason to go here is simple: Uncle Gee.  He and his charismatic approach to all things herbal delighted my entire day.  True, certain loose teas here are beyond a typical working person's budget, but there is no pressure from the staff to purchase anything after trying various samples.  They seem genuinely happy to chat with you and share what they know about tea and then wish you a good day when you leave empty handed.  Uncle Gee, in particular, doesn't hold anything back, e.g. when handing me a sample of tea, he looked straight to my boyfriend and said, "this calms the PMS craziness." 
Overall, a great little spot in Chinatown.
author: Christine M.

description: Love the constant tasting and the patience these guys showed while we tried to decide among just about all of their pu-erh!  Some very good teas too!
author: David R.

description: When you're walking around SF being a tourist and blowing your money on every little thing that catches your eye, the Vital Tea Leaf is a nice little vacation. They'll sit you down and let you try as many teas as you want. Of course you'll want to buy some afterwards (expect to pay about $15 bucks or so) but the experience will be worth it.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Ah Tea with Uncle Gee.

Its an experience you should give a try to at least once. How often do you get to sample tea for free? They have a good motto, that every person has difference tastes and you can't be told what tea you like to drink you got to just drink allot of it and try it.

They are showmen putting on a free show expecting a sale so of course they will talk and talk and get you high on tea.

For those who drink tea from a .... bag!! shame on you, your drinking unknown groudn up bits of dried plant material, at least get whole leave tea so you can see it and know whats in it. plus if its not all ground up you can easily avoid drinking it!

I have a few favorite, the bo ley and the blue people. I dont know about the latter, it doesn't really make sense to me but the tea itself tastes good! There is one called one leaf that i drink when i have to wake up, its insanely bitter and it immediately prevents you from relaxing into a state of slumber. 

So if your got a hankering for some tea and you find yourself in chinatown, well you should just stop on by, cause if you just walk on by you will hear they yell

"Dont just stand there Come inside and sit your buts down and have some TEA!"

and who argues with Uncle Gee?
author: Brian Y.

description: While taking two of my friends from Hawaii and Canada through Chinatown we stopped at Vital Tea Leaf for a free tasting. Herman helped us by brewing a number of different teas. He was personable and helpful in providing us with a wonderful experience! Thank you, Herman, it was a pleasure to taste your teas! Oh, yes, it is almost impossible to leave without buying one of the many teas that are available; the quality  is superb.
author: Judi V.

description: Fantastic,  fun tea tasting.  Staff is knowledgeable and visitors are allowed to sample many teas.
author: Jeanne B.

description: Great experience. You can sit down and taste as many teas as you like. There is a large variety of tea to satisfy any taste buds. I've been there so many times by myself and with friends, I bought enough tea to last me a life time.
author: Cindy W.

description: Free tea tasting. Who can argue with that? I actually came here because it was recommended from a friend. I told them what my problem was and they recommended a certain tea for me to buy. Hopefully it will somewhat work, but just coming here to the colorful tea commentary is enough for me. The guy who was making the tea, not sure what his name was, even chided some tourists for touching the chinese guitar-like instrument displayed in front of the store. "Hey man. That's $15,000 instrument over there. Do you see me going into your car and driving it?". That sorta made me laugh.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
i was in SF with a couple friends one day and we were walking around Chinatown.  We passed by this tea shop when one of my friends was like oh can we stop in for a bit.  i saw a sign sayin something about free tea tasting, so i figured his cheep azz wanted 2 get his free drink on.  but turned out the guy working was a family friend. So we were seated, they talked family for a bit, and had a bunch of samples of some yum*a*licious tea.  

it may not be the best deal on loose tea that you can find...and "uncle" may not provide the most accurate knowledge of tea....but what really brought you in to the shop in the 1st place....free tea tasting!!~  they make you feel comfortable, they joke around, of course you should xpect to have a some bull stories told to you.  come on now, they want you to spend your money with them....tea that can cure cancer!!~  if you believe that...then yeah....for sure will leave spending a bunch of money in this place!!!~~

i admit i did leave with a lil bag of tea, but i bought it cuz i liked the taste. not because of the fun lil story that was told about it.  (actually since i heard so many stories in souch a short amount of time....when we were done, i couldnt even remember what story went along with the tea i bought  :P  )  

this place is fun, the stories are entertaining, and the tea is good  :0)  plus that lil bag of tea lasts quite a while....i need to go back to get another bag.
author: aja h.

description:
I can't believe I haven't already reviewed this place. I've been coming to Vital tea leaf for over 9 years now. I can thank these people for my current tea obsession. This is a place where you can come and learn all about the different Chinese teas. 

Keep in mind this is NOT a place where you come to buy a cup of tea. They sell loose leaf tea, high quality loose leaf tea and sample the teas for you. If there is something that you want to try, just ask. Every time I come here I spend about an hour to an hour and a half sampling different teas. The average, I'd say, is probably 15-30 minutes for people that come in there.

They are very personable people, but they do take tea seriously. In a way they are inviting you into their home and to learn about their culture. Treat them with respect and come with an open attitude you'll have a great experience. 

One thing to note: Mint is NOT a tea! Mint is an herb that can be infused with water. I once saw an argument transpire between a customer and the owner about her desire for "Mint Tea." He attempted to explain to her that Mint is not a tea, tea is a specific plant. She insisted that Mint is a tea and that she has had it before and that he was wrong. After about 10 minutes back and forth he told her to leave the store and return when she wanted to learn about tea.

Don't let this discourage you from coming here, you won't find a better place to get indoctrinated in tea. Different teas are good for different conditions too...so if you are prone to something, like acid reflux, let them know they might have something to help. (For GARS/Acid Reflux puh erh is excellent).

Enjoy!
author: H B.

description:
I am not even a tourist and I love this place! I never knew I there was so much to learn about tea!! No pressure to buy, just sit down and sample. I must give the staff an A++++ for service and showmanship.

Got the One Leaf Bitter which is supposed to speed up your metabolism and prevent absorption of fat molecules. Tastes like sewage, looks like weed, but I think it really works!!! My favorites are the lychee black and champagne ooooooolong!
author: Kick T.

description:
Warning: When you enter this little piece of paradise smack in the middle of the insanity of Chinatown, be prepared to buy tea because the staff and the tea will blow you away and you will not be able to resist.

We entered the other store (905 Grant, just up the street) and actually just wanted to use the bathroom. But I ended up sitting down and trying tea as well. 

Jason was the guy who wowed us. 9 teas later, I had my little brewer in hand and half a pound of Blue People and Apple Ulong in hand and a gargantuan smile on my face.

What can I say, this tea made me happy.

I am going to keep coming back to this place often and I urge others to go try it for themselves instead of believing me or anyone else for that matter.
author: Jasmin F.

description:
While strolling through Chinatown after Dim Sum, we stumbled across a sign that said "Complementary Tea Tasting."  Who can say 'no' to free tea?  Not we, so for the next hour we sat at the tea bar of Vital Tea Leaf enjoying the greatest variety of teas I've ever had the opportunity to sample.  Our host walked us through different types of tea, explained what they're made of, relative caffeine content, and how they compare to the other tea we would be tasting.  He also explained how various teas are best served, how many times you can reuse certain tea leaves, and what teas are good remedies for what conditions.  When we were finished, I stood up and nearly fell over immediately.  I never realized you could get a buzz off tea, but I flew out of there that afternoon.

Vital Tea Leaf gets points for originality, customer service (our host was very engaging), selection (hundreds of different teas available to taste and purchase) and location.

They lose points for value.  That's right, kids, don't think you're going to walk in there, taste all this amazing tea, and walk out without buying anything.  And the tea there is expensive - much of it upwards of $100/lb.  They're pretty good salesmen too...

However, I have no complaints about the time or money I spent.  It was an enjoyable and educational experience, and well worth every penny.
author: Christopher M.

description:
I love stumbling upon places that turn out to be great!  

I recently visited SF for the first time, and I got the whirlwind tour from my friend.  While walking through Chinatown, I spied the "Free Tea Tasting!" sign and stopped in.  Yay, free stuff!

I do drink tea on occasion.  I cannot eat any type of Asian food without tea, it's just not right without it!  But I don't particularly LIKE tea, and therefore don't know anything about it.  After visiting Vital Tealeaf, I realized that I actually like tea quite a bit, it's just that I have been drinking crap teas my whole life!  

I have to also agree that the staff here is AWESOME!  I actually went to the 905 Grant St location, and Jason took great care of us!  Initially when we sat down, he told us that we had 5 different teas to taste.  But once we started talking, Jason brought out at least 5 more teas for us to try.  And I have to say, I learned ALOT about tea from Jason!  It is really great to talk to people about things that they are passionate about.  I asked a zillion questions, and Jason knows his stuff.  He definitely makes the subject of tea INTERESTING!  

I wish I wasn't so broke, or I definitely would have bought some of the great teas that Vital Tealeaf has.  My friend bought some Angel green tea (Jason's favorite!) which we drank the next morning.  Somehow it didn't taste the same, but I think you have to get used to brewing good tea the correct way to get the right taste.  I also love the names of the teas--Blue People Ginseng, Ginger Pine (which is neither ginger nor pine--is this just to confuse the white people?).  

FYI they also sell their teas online.  While the teas are expensive, you can use one serving of tea to make 5 cups.  So it will last a while.  And you can store tea for several years!  If you want quality, you gotta pay for it! 

I would definitely recommend this place for an interesting and educational afternoon!
author: Michelle E.

description:
This place might have the city's best bartender.  Funny, knowledgeable, and slightly off-color.  If only he served booze.

This is a great place to bring out-of-town guests so a Chinese tea expert can make fun of them.  I recommend the "Blue People" tea for newbies.
author: Chris R.

description: Great service, friendly, and informative.  They give you several samples of high-quality tea and tell you all about how it's made, where it comes from,  etc.  Fun experience, highly recommended!
author: J R.

description: I give this rate towards shipping.  I ordered tea for my boyfriend a week and a half before Christmas, I was okay with it coming after Christmas as long as he got it.  I got excited though to see that there was a two day shipping, but to my dismay it took 8 days and arrived on Christmas Eve.  I was not happy because I spent 17 dollars on shipping for it to come in two days.  Along with that one of the teas that I was looking forward to most to give to my boyfriend, they sent the wrong kind.  Thank fully he liked it, but next time I'm finding a different place to purchase tea.
author: Hannah W.

description: For serious tea drinkers only. Don't expect to buy a cup of tea to drink here. Instead, you get personable attention from the people educating you on teas. Their not afraid to turn you down as a customer if you're disruptive. Complimentary teas are served in a tiny tea cup that's large enough to take a few sips. They don't try to sell you something you're not interested either. In fact when they found out we were in San Fran for our honeymoon they gave us a complimentary bag of tea worth $20.
author: Sarah L.

description: Welcoming atmosphere, FREE tea tastings with lots of information on the health/medicinal benefits of each tea. I bought the baby green tea and have been enjoying it all week. Very high quality.
author: Sarah E.

description:
This is MY tea shop! I tell my friends that come to visit - "I've gotta take you to my tea shop in Chinatown". I've been coming here for YEARS! So much that they actually remember me :-) Great place for a date, or pop in on your own, relax and drink some tea. It's the best. Here's how it works...

Vital Tea Leaf is a tea "bar", not just a tea "shop". They'll give you samples of all sorts of tea, and tell you all the homeopathic benefits. Careful though - they'll hit on your girlfriend too ;-) All in good fun. They don't accept tips, if you like the experience - spend your $5 on some tea. Or better yet - buy a 1/4 pound of Blue People (that'll cost a little more than $5 though). You'll sample 10 - 15 different types of tea, and really taste the range in flavors. They import TONS (literally - tons) of tea direct from China. These guys are so meticulous about their tea, that they go directly to the tea farms themselves and hand pack all the tea - so they know exactly what they're getting. It's all organic - and it's all goooood. Hell of an experience. Go here. Become a regular like me! I actually have a pot of Black Oolong brewin' now. Gotta run. GO HERE!!!
author: Eli S.

description:
I stumbled upon this place about a year and a half ago, running errands with my mother. Of course, the "Free Tea Tasting" lure brought us in. What could be more tempting on a cold day? I was charmed by the set up of the place, which is fairly laid back and everything's kept simple. However, I was a bit less impressed with some of their teas. I refuse to drink tea using teabags now, and just worship loose leaf tea. But while tasting tea from this place I feel that the quality of a lot of them is less than perfect. Plus it's true that some of the names of the teas sound entirely made up on the spot.

I agree with a few of the other reviews, but it is obviously a tea place for an inexperienced tea lover. What un-knowledgeable tea consumer would purchase tea they can't see? And thus the existence of a lot of glass containers in their shop. What else is not to love for a run-of-the-mill tea lover? They even give "free" quantities of tea to keep them coming back.

Despite the lack of quality for Vital Tea Leaf, I still enjoy their "Angel Green Tea" and "Lychee Black Tea." But I can't admit to liking much else.
author: Alaka F.

description: Uncle Gee is awesome.  I got such an education in tea and tea brewing while I was there tasting teas.  I love this place.  A girl was playing a harp-like instrument, the tea was amazing.  One of them was fresh like grass.  They were all good.  Usually I don't like rose tea but the rose tea uncle Gee made for me was excellent.  The prices here are high, tourist prices you could say.  But the freshness is top notch and the experience is awesome.  I'll be going back to visit my "Uncle Gee" for the rest of my life.  The tea I drank there makes me feel good.  I got a little brewing thing and some tea and so did my aunt.  Good times.  Good tea, there is nothing to feel guilty about with tea, just drink it and have fun.
author: Cynthia B.

description: MY FAVORITE TEA PLACE!!! Oh Uncle Gee I miss you already. I had stumbled upon this place and it turned out to be the highlight of our stay in san francisco. Free tea till we couldnt drink any more tea at all. And they had this one tea, I forget what it was called, but it tasted like buttered popcorn. Too bad it was pricey. But the rose and mango tea was my second and third favorites. I left here with tea, and some more knowledge and self worth than when I came in. And on top of that, I'm ordering more online.
author: Katie P.

description: It's a real Chinese tea shop so you don't necessarily go here for a spot.  What you do come here for is to learn about and test and purchase high-qualitiy teas.  The quality and amount of choices along with the helpful staff is par excellence.  Check it out when the weather in the city is cold and you need to rest your tired feet.
author: Daniel C.

description: You must go here if you are in Chinatown!! Free tea tasting & great servive!
author: Edgar G.

description: My son (14) never drank tea before we stepped into Vital Tea and he walked out of the place a devoted tea drinker. We especially loved the Blue tea, but enjoyed the others as well. Our tea barrista was friendly and funny and did not pressure us for a second to buy anything (we did because we chose to do so). We loved Vital Tea and only wish there was one in our neck of the woods (Philadelphia). Yes, we were tourists - but happy ones who were treated well and did not feel at all ripped off. It was a fun experience we hope to experience again on our next trip to San Francisco. Thanks for the fun and the tea lesson!
author: Jamie R.

description:
This place was SO entertaining. 
Of course the guy had some lewd and crude jokes, yells and is quite outrageous, but very entertaining.
They have a lot of these places in chinatown but my friend Prasant took us here because he knows its fun. =)
He yells at you to sit down and try tea for FREE.
Their tea tastes really good.  They have different teas for all kinds of ailments.  The gimmick is to get you to buy tea of course, which is really expensive for some kinds but they taste good! 
I really like the Angels blend, the Siberian Rose, the white tea, the butter oolong tea, and the green tea.
Tasty!  Lots of tea though, and he will keep serving it to you until you leave because they have 350 plus kinds.
If you ever in chinatown and tired of walking up and down and looking at the same kind of stores selling the same kind of thing, come to this tea place!  fun!!  (unless you are easily offended, then it wont be fun, probably should stay away)
i bought some ailment tea for my dad but being a tea fanatic he mumbled something about it being from china and the tea leaves there might have more pesticides. =/ i dont know.
author: Ami T.

description: We had a very good experience at Vital Tea Leaf. The lady was a bit too much "sales" initially, but when she found out that we knew something about tea, she was very helpful in finding some good teas for us. She was very knowledgeable about the teas they had; and they had a lot. Definitely will go there again when I'm in town.
author: Christian W.

description: What a cool tea shop! We stopped by here while I was exploring all the stores in Chinatown yesterday and the people who worked there were super friendly, and all the tea they allowed us to sample was amazing, with a very authentic taste to it. They explain the benefits of each tea as well as tea talk with each pouring of a new tea. The other people checking it out were very friendly as well and it was nice resting spot to all the heavy shopping I was doing in the area. Just the ambiance of the place exemplifies a cultural center of San Francisco and all the pictures and letters that people write brings a sense of community that places in Florida just do not have. It is one of the beautiful things about San Francisco and California, each place here, even places that are similar have their own thing about them and that's what I love. The employees were funny and made me feel like I had come to a new home: a tea home.
author: Carlos H.

description: Great place to try tea! Stumbled on this place and you barely have to walk in the door without being handed a shot glass of tea. Tried several different ones and they mixed and matched according to what we usually like and what we didn't like about the offerings. Felt absolutely no pressure to buy, which will make me a repeat customer. Prices were reasonable to a little steep.
author: J E.

description: I love this tea shop because there is a wide variety, knowledgable and friendly staff, and of course a relaxing and quiet enviornment. I really enjoy when the lady with the long hair is behind the counter cause she will be happy to help yo narrow down the many choice down to a few that suite your taste. One of my favorite places in the city.
author: Lo T.

description:
Hmm... well after reading teapot's review, I'm definitely having second thoughts about this place. I do want to say that TECHNICALLY oolong is sometimes referred to as "blue tea," though I am not sure if that is what Vital Tea sells under the name. 

Like I've said before, I'm a tea lover, but I'm not a tea traditionalist. I don't know that much about tea, especially not asian tea... so maybe I got cought in their trap, but I really did enjoy my experience there. Tiny cups and tea tasting, with friendly and fun salespeople. 

I don't know.
author: Sasha W.

description:
