Very nice, showy tasting, like what you get in a Japanese steak house. To a Chinese person, it looks like a joke, but I do like the father (the owner) and son there. They seemed to speak of nonsense just because the way the act, but whatever I heard the day when I was there, it was so true to the Chinese wisdom in the chinese medicine. 

I like the variety of tea that they carry in the store. They are good for real tea drinkers who know their teas, as well as tea drinkers who see it as an beverage. They also carry a lot of herbal tea, and floral tea. I liked most of the teas that I got for the tasting, but my favorites are the Ginseng Iron Goddess, and this milky oolong. 

What I don't like about this place, is that they over charge you BY FAR. Well, it's China town and most people there are tourists so, i guess it's a good business practice. 

I like the old daddy here. He knows a lot about the traditional values in chinese medicine, and he is extremely nice, as well as the son. Nice people, with good showmanship.
author: Yuchi C.

description: First time I went to this place I thought, "I drink coffee, tea's alright, but I'll stick with coffee and amuse my friend who brought me here and try it." First off, I love the way the inside looks, my kind of place. The guy who helped us was really helpful and nice, let us try 7 or 8 different teas. My tea experience before was limited to tea bags, alright, but not for me. After coming here my eyes were opened to real tea. The flavors of all the teas are amazing. I'm liking it more than coffee now. My first visit I got Ginseng Oolong or more popularly known as Blue People. Drink it in the morning and usually feel better than when I drink coffee. Second time I went got Jasmine Pearl to help calm my mind at night. When I run out, I'll definitely go back.
author: Wes K.

description:
The variety of teas this place carries merits 5 stars all by itself. An incredible selection. Its just unbelievable. AND their best sellers are best sellers for a reason - the Korean Ginsing Oolong is absolutely delicious and cannot be found anywhere else. If you don't believe me, try it when you go (as soon as you step through the door their brewing you tea to try) and then try to find it anywhere else.

Vital tea leaf seems to be family run and is one of two tea shops that this family owns and operates within a few blocks of each other (I guess business is booming). I wouldn't rely too much on their knowledge of tea in general though, most of what they have to say involves you either losing weight or curing your hangover. 

However, as I said, the teas themselves are outrageously good. So yeah, 5 stars.
author: Michael K.

description: Had a great time trying teas with my girlfriend. When I run out of my tea supply I'll definitely pay another visit.
author: Glen T.

description: This is the best place to get great tea in the bayarea- no snobbishness and a whole lot of knowledge. They are great! I will only be going here from now on-
author: Clifford S.

description:
I'm giving it four stars only because of the other reviews I read on the page.  Otherwise I felt it would warrant a 5.  DO NOT come into Vital Tea Leaf unless you're planning on spending money.  We went to the nearby fortune cookie factory and saw a sign.  Everyone in my party loves tea, so we all figured it'd be an experience...and it was.

The free tasting was great, and "Uncle Gee" is certainly a man with lots of charisma.  He spouts Chinese Wisdom like it's his job, and sells tea like no one I've ever seen.  Everyone tastes all kinds of different teas...and most of them are absolutely delicious.  I can't vouch for the truth in his description of each tea.  I'm not sure how much the bitter tea helps to lower cholesterol, but I do know that there is SOME truth to Chinese usage of herbs.  

So, after he gets to know you and pretends like you're a member of his "family," he starts the sales push.  The funny thing is that at the end of the 45 minute tasting ordeal, you're eating out of his hand.  "What should we be getting?" wondered a member of my party.  "Well, I really liked the Blue People" countered her husband.  "Oh, so I guess that'll be a quarter pound of Blue People?  No need to get the Ginseng Oolong if you're getting that.  [tone lowers] Yes, that's $120 per pound." says Uncle Gee.  Four teas later and you walk out having spent $150 on tea.  

Highly overpriced?  I don't know...I'm not that much of a tea connoisseur.  At least that's what the people at Vital Tea Leaf made me feel like ("You drink from the bag?  Don't even speak to me...").  Still, the experience was worth it.  And I'm sure I'll enjoy the tea....so, if you're in the neighborhood, stop by and say hi to Uncle Gee.  Be prepared, however, to open up your wallet...
author: Zach S.

description:
Spent an hour + there last week on my birthday. Kenny was fabulous - funny, educational, really enjoyed the delicious teas he presented. Really like the colors and the feeling of the space --- felt like I landed in Shanghai momentarily. It kinda turned into a party scene. everyone hanging out and talking. Highly recommend it!

postscript: been drinking the energizing tea and have been coffee-free for a few days and feel great. Also got a digestive and relaxing tea. And the cool glass teapot which rocks.
author: Victoria Z.

description: We stumbled on this place. I wasn't thrilled to sample tea, I'd prefer wine! The experience was very good, atmosphere was fun, "Uncle Gee" was priceless. I learned lots about the benefits of tea, and walked out with $60 worth. I had a blast.
author: Paul R.

description: Uncle G and John are really knowledgeable about the teas! very funny and nice. tea is good too.
author: Melanie E.

description:
My friend and I had so much fun when we came here.  The "bartender" was so knowledgable and friendly.  It was really fun for the two of us, who are both really into tea, to sit down and get to try such a wide variety of tea.  My favorite was the Lychee Black, my friend really liked the Iron Goddess Green Tea.  We also both liked the Ginseng Green tea.  The milk tea was a bit odd and neither of use really enjoyed it that much, although it was still nice to be able to taste it at least once.  

Overall we tried about 8 different teas and although the tea seems a bit expensive, since they teach you how to get the most out of your purchase (how much to brew, the best way to maximize flavor with a little tea, and which ones you can reuse), and it's risk-free since you get to taste it first for free and buy only what you like, its worth it.  I will defininetly bring visitors here again and may even go back myself next time I'm in the city.
author: Jaclyn S.

description:
I do agree some peoe talked about quality of their tea.
Probably over priced, however, i enjoyed tea tasting.
If you don't buy too much tea, it'll be fine.
author: Hyun P.

description:
Vital TeaLeaf is a shop on a road in Chinatown that looks normal, but inside magic happens.  The owner is the original rock star of tea and he makes this often intimidating beverage come to life through free tastings.  That's right, sit down, and he starts filling you up with different exotic teas that you've never heard of before and that he claims will cure a number of common afflictions.

The guy is just plain funny and it turns out that he has been asked to be on TV so don't think you're going to "discover" him.  The tea itself I will leave to more sophisticated palates than mine.  I like black tea and green tea.  Seemed like the more expensive and more health enhancing the teas got, the more they tasted like ass, but I'm sure that's because of my cro-magnon taste buds.  Seriously, go see this guy!  You'll be sending me a thank you note afterwords for recommending it!
author: Chris A.

description: Sure, Grant street is touristy--but I have to admit, I had a great time here--and I learned a lot.  Vital Leaf sells loose leaf teas, but allows you to taste them for free, with no obligation to buy.  The tea tasting itself is fun--we tried about 10 different teas, and Wayne, our brewer/pourer explained the differences between all of them.  He was quite entertaining as well.  And, I did buy a couple as well---the prices are similar to Samovar or any other place that imports tea.  Above all, this is a great place to bring friends from out of town, to do something that is a bit out of the norm for tourists---and perfect for that cold san francisco summer!
author: Sameer D.

description: Not cheap by any means but well worth it and if you get the chance to drink tea with Kenny, don't talk, just listen and enjoy some fine tea.
author: Jon P.

description:
the rowdyest bar tenders I know serve tea,
     And they serve tea here,
                 and its very nice tea.

And they'll serve you free tea all night, 
   that is, if your that hot date knows as much about tea as them.

my favs: "Ginseng Oolong" and "Puh- are" (sp?)
author: Asa D.

description: If you like tea this is where you need to go. The staff is so knowledgeable and they make you feel warm and welcome. The teas can be expensive yet delicious.
author: Delroy H.

description: My daughter and her friends went to SF Chinatown for her birthday and stop by Vital Leaf.  Uncle Gee was friendly, fun and informative.  It was truly a great experience that everyone who goes to Chinatown should do.  I felt wonderful for a week after drink two of their teas.  I look forward to returning to tea taste again.
author: Constance P.

description: Tea sounded like a good idea, so we settled in at the bar.  We were unaware of what was in store for us.  John was hysterical.  Every tea was amazing and we sat there for more than an hour. The guys next to us were there for over two hours.  We were given samples of about 10 teas and were given explanations of what they can do for you.  After a belly full of tea and even more laughs we each left with a bag of tea.  John allowed us to take his picture but specifically asked to not have his picture on facebook or yelp.  You will have to go yourself to meet him.  I do warn you, if you do not pay attention jasmine tea balls will be thrown at you.
author: Megan P.

description: This place gets a lot of great reviews by people who think pouring hot water over potpourri and sugar is tea.  The Uncle G character puts a show on for all the tourists who think he is the cutest thing while Uncle G tells them lie after lie about tea.  Then he sells them low quality crap.  None of the teaware in the store has a price tag so they can charge you whatever they think they can get from you.  If you want high quality tea in Chinatown, I would suggest Red Blossom across and down the street.  It's expensive, but the quality is much better than the schwag you'll get at this tourist trap.
author: G M.

description: I came across this shop while in China town visiting San Francisco. I met Herman which was so helpful, friendly, and just cool. We tasted at least 5 different teas and he educated us on what the benefits of some of them where. We left with Rose tea which I found so aromatic and we also grabbed the Jasmine tea. I would recommend stopping by this shop and relaxing for a few.
author: emely j.

description: Learned SOOOO much about tea. I have never been to a tea tasting before and neither had my date. We went here and the experience was his favorite part of the date and he's not even a very big tea drinker. He has kidney problems and it really inspired him to start drinking more T.  I learned so much about health benefits, brewing, and proper terminology. It was better after we sat down and got more acquainted as more people joined us. They won't overly pressure you to buy tea but they expect you too. The purpose of the tasting is to find your palatte and buy a tea you like, not to just taste free teas all day. We must have tried over ten. The guy is abit smug and the woman took awhile to warm up but they really are nice and fun to be around. I got coconut green tea which tastes like coconut water which is my favorite drink *so good* will have to take my mother here when she visits. The tea is IMPECABLE! Highest quality and they won't keep anything that is close 2 the end of it's shelf life. I wanted to give them 4stars because it was awkward coming in wanting to try teas and not knowing what we wanted to try *there are so many* but after getting comfortable the experience really was great. 4stars for the experience, but 5 for the highest quality tea i have ever had in my life
author: Brittainie B.

description: Wonderful atmosphere to taste teas, but they really put the pressure on you to buy.
author: Sammantha M.

description: Great service whether in the store or on the phone. Very accomodating and helpful. Willing to send tea samples with you order, just ask!
author: Jim M.

description: This is a tea lovers haven.  This bar offers up a wonderful selection of teas and an education to go along with it.  Stumbled onto it when I was in SanFran a few weeks ago and am very sad that my hometown does not have one... Great place to stop in when you are in Chinatown.
author: Jessica G.

description: We came here with friends from NYC and after dimsum we decided to come in here for tea tasting. This is our first time and we were 5 and joined the other 3 people along the counter. The rep. (I think he might be the boss!) was gregarious and friendly and knowledgeable and he would answer every questions I asked lol... it was a very informative and educational session and IT WAS FREE. There was also no obligation to buy but I bought the Angel tea leaves after tasting. Mind you, it taste so different from the other green tea I've ever tasted and the tea leaves changes colour from brown to light green!  To watch that process was so refreshing itself not to mention the taste!  I believe I was drinking a happy magic potion :)
author: Bella A.

description: Bunk information, bunk prices--there are so many other wonderful places to get tea in Chinatown and all over the city--why come here to get ripped off?
author: Caroline C.

description: Amazing. Strolled down Grant Ave with my wife and daughter who flew in from NY to visit. After getting yelled at as we looked in and thought about steping in, it was the best tea tasting experience for all of us. Uncle Gee is great. What a treat to spend time with this showman. Uncle Gee rolls tea education and relationship education into one great sitting. No pressure to buy anything, but we did, hard to turn down the good stuff. We'll be back.
author: Raymond S.

description: "Free Tea Tasting" and it's not a come-on. In the back, gotta love the maoist youth painting. We tasted 12 to 16 teas in rapid succession and the vast majority were splendid. The servers provided a taste of background for each one and were genuine in their pride of the tea. The tea was all properly prepared and best of all: NO pressure to buy. Another group at the bar chose to discuss Honda Civic speed parts while sipping away through the gauntlet of teas. I ended up buying 5 "buds" of silver tea with a raspberry flower and chrysanthemum inside that "bloom" when brewed in a clear glass teapot. I've had this tea before elsewhere and this was first rate for only $2 per bud. I don't know if that's the cheapest, but it seems less than other shops I've reviewed. It's at least 1/2 what it costs to order in a tea room.
author: Brandon R.

description: Dang it!  I feel like I've been taken for a ride.  I stopped by here last weekend to fill up my empty tea caddy's.  I originally wanted to just get a small sample of a couple different teas and then come back later if I liked them.  But then the guy behind the counter started going on about how I should at least get enough for a month and to try different grades.  Next thing I knew I walked out of there spending like 5 times more then I wanted.  Oh well, I supposed it partially my fault too.  Need to show more self restraint next time I'm shopping and not just follow everything the saleman says.
author: Smokey G.

description: I will not waste my words nor time writing a lengthy review for such a silly place.  Buyers beware, this place WILL rip you off.  "Blue Tea"?  More like aspartam-covered sub-par oolong that will taste like cardboard after one brewing.  Tea is a thing to be enjoyed for its finery, its refined tastes, its simple nature.  This place turns it into an overpriced used car.  Forgive me, but no, none for me!
author: Scott N.

description: I'm sure some of the tea here is probably decent--except I doubt the people who work there have the knowledge to know where it is located.  The in-your-face showmanship and stunts this place pulls (girls sitting outside playing the Guzheng) is strictly for the tourists, or for those who want to feel they are back on the mainland, aggressive hawkers in your face spouting hyperbolic claims.
author: Nick H.

description: This place is a nice sit down tea house where you can view, smell and even taste a large assortment of teas. The owner is amazingly nice and charming and the sitdown tea bar atmosphere calls for a cordial ambiance perfect for striking up a conversation with the person sitting next to you. Great for a cheap date, ideal for a tea conosour who loves everything from rare white teas to delicious oolongs to spicy and smoky wild pu-erh.
author: Andrew K.

description: Ok ok so I got pulled in by the free tastings but now I'm hooked on tea. I used to enjoy a good green tea now and again but now I constantly drink baby chrysanthemum and blue tea. The people there are really helpful, when i had a scratchy throat I went to them and they let me sample different teas until I found one that worked. The prices are a bit steep but my 1/4 of a pound has lasted me awhile. Very good for loose leaf tea newbies.
author: Andrea B.

description:
Visit Vital Tea Leaf for the spectacle on a busy Saturday, and only if you're not a tea snob.

Make no mistake - Vital Tea Leaf will absolutely not be the best deal on tea that you can find in Chinatown, nor will the salespeople have encyclopedically accurate knowledge of the teas.

However, the real reason to visit is to see the old guy at work on a busy Saturday. I can guess that the average Westerner without a strong knowledge of tea can gain a good, friendly introduction to the tea and also watch as he skillfully convinces skeptical tourists to relax for some tea tasting (and sales, no doubt). The salesmanship on display is almost worth the price of the tea alone. I sat and sipped while hearing him literally shouting at people to get their ass in and try some tea. After spotting a Ten-Ren tea package, he and his salesman convinced a party of 5 to come in, offered to buy the cheap tea, then brewed it in front of them for a comparison taste-test against the house Jasmine tea.

It was an experience I am glad that I did not miss, although I did end up spending a pretty penny on tea. I didn't once feel that I was being ripped off or sold really hard on the tea. You can't walk into this place as a tourist and think that you're somehow getting a price-sensitive experience. No, it's definitely a show, and it's a show that I'd glady advise my friends to go see.
author: Gordon L.

description: My out-of-town friend pointed this place out to me as we ambled through Chinatown. Now, I'm not sure of the accuracy of the information or the reasonableness of the pricing of the teas. I did have a lot of fun trying different teas and chatting with the staff. If they are misleading, at least they are engaging and funny! My friend bought some tea, though I did not...I did feel that the staff was a bit pushy and I prefer not to make purchases in those situations. I may have to go back after doing a little research and pricing comparison, to get a better idea. It was a fun little detour though.
author: Barbs J.

description: Free tea tasting, fortune cookies, comfortable seats, entertaining people serving the tea, tea education, and the list goes on and on. What more can you ask for? This tea shop is beyond words, amazing. Unlike some other tea shops, when you walk in, there isn't a awkward feeling, and the creaking of tiles as you walk into the store. This tea bar as I should call it is fun, exciting, and definitely not boring. The tea you get at Vital Tea Leaf is definitely worth the price(: I LOVE this store! GO GO GO, the people there will entertain you, and you'll begin having a new love for tea. It'll be love at first sip ;D
author: Leah C.

description:
We are very much beginners in the art of tea and stumbled across this place ysterday while out in the city. It's been ages since I've been to chinatown and this place struck me as new, then again I have a poor sense of orientation, it might have been there all along and I might have passed it each time, never considering going inside.

I have to say I felt a bit intimidated attending a tea tasting for the first time. How do you start? What do you say? I only really know green tea and I like a light tea. I'm not much into black tea but I know oolong is a little stronger.

We sat next to an out of town couple that also seemed very curious and knew little if not less than us about tea, but wanted to learn. We've spent probably close to 45min. in here learning about the different teas and getting a real valuable education. The tea master is great, very patient, very knowledgeable and we felt that purchasing tea here was worth the cost. We now have a tea that benefits both of us and is we both enjoy. 

This is definetly worth going into, trying, taking a look around and learning more about tea. This would be great for out of towners, a nice addition into chinatown. We'll definetly come back soon (once we're out of tea, to replenish)..now that we finally know the name of the teas..;)
author: Trinity X.

description:
A friend of mine recommended this place & I'm glad she did.
Uncle Gee has a special tea for any type of ailment.  He recommended Blue Tea (good for people with anxiety) and let me tell you ..it totally works.  
Also, I bought some bitter tea which helps with weight loss.  It looks like a joint and smells a little like beef jerky but it totally works.  
I highly recommend.
author: Carolyn P.

description: love this place. my wife and i happened upon it a few years back when we were visiting SF. now there are many imitators, even in NYC. their teas are great. sometimes the prepackaged stuff seems a little inferior (twigs and stems in the mix( so make sure to get fresh packages made from the containers displayed). definitely the best place of its kind tho. it's great to be able to taste teas before buying them and these guys will let you taste any of their varieties first.
author: Dan M.

description: I stopped into Vital Tea Leaf today for the first time with my husband and son.  We really had a pleasant experience.  We were served by James who was really knowledgeable, interesting and super nice.  We learned a lot about the different types of teas and sampled about 12 to 14 different varieties.  The teas were very tasty and of a high quality.  It's a must visit shop in China Town!
author: Debra S.

description: UNCLE GEE IS THE BEST!   He will lure you in with his charisma and you will leave with so much tea knowledge you will not know what to do with yourself.  The place is very welcoming that you come in a stranger and leave family.  It is pretty rare that you find a shop that is warm welcoming from the instant that you enter in Chinatown.  Sit down and try the free tea tasting.  I tried 10 teas and felt healthier than ever.  I loved the Oolong Ginseng, Lychee Black and Blue Tea.   The experience was unforgettable!  I would recommend stopping by if you have some time, 45 minutes will suffice.
author: Shiho F.

description:
i'm just beginning my tea addiction here and vital leaf is the first tea joint i've experienced in chinatown.

i've visited teavana briefly and they've both been full of very helpful tea mongers.

vital tea leaf has a bunch of fun characters who are full of energy and recommended some very nice teas for me to try after my first visit.

vital tea leaf has a nice variety of teas and accessories (nice pots, cups, sets, etc) which gives it a bit of an advantage over most of the other tea shops i've entered.

i can't say much for the prices though.  i'll need more experience shopping around first.
author: Richard C.

description: I don't know if i love this place or hate it! The Guy who sells you tea is straight forward and i had a great experience. That is after i left and the zen of the tea left my body and i thought maybe hes a tea Nazi!
author: Kristina S.

description:
First I want to thank all those that wrote such fantastic reviews on Vital Tea, especially TeaPot, Hitomi and Kyle. As you can see from these reviews, this place is special. It makes some delighted and others furious, but it makes all who go there have strong feelings and a powerful experience, and for that alone I recommend it. 

I like going here and I bring friends often. It is fun and a real unusual experience. I cherish that. I am not very knowledgeable about tea, though I have been learning more recently. I purchased the Blue Tea believing it was a green tea, and after comparing the leaves of the tea to the pictures of gynotstemma, I have to agree that it appears I did not buy tea at all. So be it. I paid $20 for a 1/4 pound of herbal infusion, information about tea (some correct, some not) and a really great time. It was $20 well spent and I drink my Blue "Tea" daily.

I highly recommend going to Vital Tea and experiencing what they offer. Accept that much of what they say is story telling and that is great. If you really want to learn about tea, do some research. If you just want to have some fun, go there. And buy a little tea while your there...$15 will get an occasional tea drinker enough for months and it will only be a few dollars more than down the street. After you experience Vital Tea, and you have done a little research, you can go somewhere where the prices are better but the service is not as good. 

I totally understand TeaPot's and Hitomi's frustration, but it would be really nice if some of the "better" or more honest tea places learned from Vital Tea and started providing more service to the tea newbies. Until then, most of us will be at Vital Tea (or Pete's).
author: Ian S.

description: An absolute gem.  If you have ever wondered about Chinese tea, the benefits of tea, and the true pros and cons of tea then I would recommend that you make a trip here.  The tasting was free and so was the extensive knowledge of the shop owners who spoken good English.  Clean, open and welcoming, Vital is the place to be for tea lovers.  We love tea and this was the friendliest place we have been in the Bay Area.  Loads of pots, cups, etc for sale but the tea and the service is why we will go back again.  Bought some lychee jasmine - yummmmmmy !  A surprise find in Chinatown. Just delightful
author: Beautiful B.

description: This place maybe over priced for buying tea buy I found it a charming an aesthetically pleasing tasting.  I would recommend this place for out of towners - it is really fun and you don't have to buy anything. We bought about $10 worth of tea but one could easily spend a hundred bucks.
author: Ruby F.

description:
definately gimmicky and salesmany, but that seems to be the chinese way so that is not by any means a negative point in this specific review.

i do in fact buy tea here, as they do have a good selection, and despite other people's invalid and stupid opinion that they can get equal substitute tea significantly cheaper elsewhere, this is not true.
author: christopher a.

description: I've been taking folks from out of town here for a few years now as part of my standard Chinatown/North Beach tour. Despite Uncle Gee putting me in the dungeon multiple times and Johnny saying all sorts of crazy stuff about genitalia...I keep coming back. I don't know where they find these people but they are freaking crazy, and wildly entertaining. One of the top ten things to do for free in San Francisco. Thank you guys for all the tea and good times.
author: Tim B.

description: They were friendly, patient and generous. Pretty amazing for chinatown, even if it is on Grant. Definitely worth a stop in if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Gabriela O.

description: I was showing my UK friend around San Francisco and I took him for a walk through Chinatown. We ran across this place and he had to stop in because obviously he's a fan of tea. The staff was extremely funny and friendly. A great place to meet people from all over. You could tell they were targeting the tourists to come into the shop. It was a fun experience and we drank our tea and left. They didn't seem happy that we left without buying anything, but whatever. I mean, your sign says, "Free Tea" and you were persistent for us to come in and sit. Don't be mad, you brought this upon yourself! Ha! However, the experience was fun and memorable so when I go back I'll buy some tea if I need some, sure who cares, just because they are so friendly. Why not? I'd rather pay more for tea there than some boring place. The claims they make about certain teas being good for particular stuff like smoking, heavy drinking, etc. I don't really think has any merit. Yet, I'll agree that tea has its benefits over soda any day of the week. Anyway, fun place, good experience, good tea, and great for tourists.
author: Matt M.

description:
I stumbled upon this tea shop as i was wandering around china town, looking for the furtune cookie factory, because I had a group of 15 german girls that I would need to show around the next day. I went in, and sat down and Uncle Gee made me try all these wonderful teas, one after the other. teaching us of their properties, why you brew them the way they do, the history, the 5 types, and all that good stuff. I was so much fun, and Ive enevr left that store without a new tea in hand. This was October of 2007, and since then Ive gone back countless times, and I feel like its almost a home away from home at the tea shop.
Ive brought over 40 people to that shop, and everyone has loved the experience. From getting tea samples from Ming to talking to Uncle Gee and Jin, every visit was worth the trek into chinatown.

i strongly recommend this place to anyone and everyone! :)
author: Joanna Y.

description: I really enjoy this place. Their tea is delicious, but pricey - definitely worth the money though. I highly recommend it. They have 3 shops in SF Chinatown, pay them a visit you will not regret it.
author: qomag K.

description: it's all about the peeps here. the reviews below are right! it's entertainment really. the tea was pretty good too. i actually bought some, as did my friend-who ended up having buyer's remorse. "$40 on tea!?" it's all good. consider it the price of an hour of entertainment from good old "Uncle Gee."
author: Tiffany W.

description: Beautiful place. Nice people. Free tasting. Quaint and to the point. Not snobby at all. Just sweet people and good tea.
author: Jessica L.

description: we recently visited vital tea leaf and found it to be one of the most pleasant experiences we had in san francisco.  sf is a great place for a vacation or getaway and vita tea leaf should not be missed.  the gentleman who helped us select the teas we purchased was very knowledgable and in addition provided us and others in the shop with about 30 minutes of tea education and entertainment.  he was not only knowledgeable but also non-intimedating.  this is a great place to visit while in chinatown or better yet make it a destination.
author: kay a.
